21-0661.summary: Recommendation to approve the minutes of the Economic Development and Finance Committee meeting held Tuesday, April 6, 2021.A motion was made by Chair Mungo, seconded by Vice Chair Richardson, to approve recommendation.  The motion carried by the following vote:Page 1 of 4411 W. 21-0662.summary: Recommendation to receive and file a report from Economic Development staff on 1st Quarter 2021 Economic Indicators and Sales Tax Study Report for 2019 to 2020 for the City of Long Beach.John Keisler, Director of Economic Development, spoke; and introduced Eric Romero, Business Development Officer.Eric Romero, Business Development Officer, spoke; and provided aPowerPoint presentation.Chair Mungo spoke.Vice Chair Richardson spoke.Eric Romero, Business Development Officer, spoke.A dialogue ensued between Vice Chair Richardson and Eric Romero, Business Development Officer.Chair Mungo spoke.Vice Chair Richardson spoke.A dialogue ensued between Chair Mungo and Vice Chair Richardson.Councilwoman Allen spoke.Eric Romero, Business Development Officer, spoke.Chair Mungo spoke.A dialogue ensued between Chair Mungo and Eric Romero, Business Development Officer.A motion was made by Chair Mungo, seconded by Vice Chair Richardson, to approve recommendation.  The motion carried by the following vote:Yes: 3 - Mungo, Richardson and AllenPage 2 of 4411 W. OCEAN BOULEVARDCIVIC CHAMBERS, 3:00 PMTUESDAY, JULY 13, 2021CITY OF LONG BEACHECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCE COMMITTEE MINUTES3.
21-0662.transcript:
SPEAKER_00:  Vice-Show Richardson. 
SPEAKER_00:  Eltonwoman Allen. Aye. 
SPEAKER_00:  Motion carries. Thank you. 
SPEAKER_00:  Next item, please. 
SPEAKER_00:  Item 2 is a recommendation to receive and file a report from Economic Development Staff on 1st quarter, 2021, Economic Indicators. 
SPEAKER_00:  and sales tax study report for 2019 to 2020. 
SPEAKER_04:  Thank you. Just for a point of history, I remember fighting really hard to get access to this report. There was a time where a previous city manager said, council members really shouldn't be able to dig into the details of this. You can look at it at a high level. And I'm really proud of the fact that we have been able to get additional reports and detail that breaks out the city into lower levels by industry and geography. And I think our ability to compare ourselves to other cities and specifically by category really gives us an opportunity to focus our efforts on areas that have the highest opportunity for return on investment. So I'm excited to see this presentation. 
SPEAKER_04:  May we have a staff report. 
SPEAKER_03:  Good afternoon city council members and it's great to bring back quarterly updates on the sales tax and economic indicators. I'm going to actually turn it over to our in-house expert Eric Romero, who is our business development officer, and tracks these measures as part of his own work plan. So Eric, you want to take it away? 
SPEAKER_01:  Sure, thank you, John. Good afternoon, a chair of the Economic Development and Finance Committee and members of the Economic Development and Finance Committee. I'm Eric Romero, I'm the city's business development officer. So today we'll provide to you just an economic indicators report, and the focus will be on sales tax revenue today. 
SPEAKER_01:  So as you know, we've mentioned before and as you're aware, the Economic Development and Finance Committee has received several local economic indicators presentations in the past. It's been some time since we've done some of these, so we're excited to present some new data to you today. Today's presentation will focus specifically, as I just mentioned, on sales tax revenue. So some of the data that we'll be looking at is citywide sales tax revenue by fiscal year. We'll look at sales tax revenue comparisons across different geographic areas, like the County of Los Angeles, the state of California, Southern California, some other cities that have been recommended by our sales tax consultant, HDL companies. We'll also look at sales tax surplus in gap comparison by retail categories in the past. We've referred to these as sales tax leakage reports. And then we'll look at sales tax revenue by major industry groups, and then we'll provide a brief overview of AB147, which is the Marketplace Facilitator Act that has impacted some of the city's sales tax revenues. And so we'll cover some of those details. We'll also end the presentation with some questions for you all. So now that we're going to get back into the swing of providing these quarterly economic indicator reports, we'd like to hear from you all exactly what data you would like for us to look into and report to you on a quarterly basis. And if it all possible, we would like to standardize the indicators that we are sharing with you. Of course, if there are special requests, we will do our best to do our research and assess what information we can make available to you all so that we can present at the different economic indicators. So we'll end with a little bit of a brainstorming session. It's that's okay with you all. 
SPEAKER_01: ских ال dabei 
SPEAKER_01:  So this first slide here looks at sales tax revenue by fiscal year. And we'll look at the last three years or the last two years and then FY21 as well. So from FY18 to FY19, we had a 2.7% increase. So a moderate increase in our sales tax revenue citywide. And we did see a 7.6% decrease from FY19 to FY20. I think it's safe to say that a lot of that decrease was due to the COVID-19 pandemic and its impacts on our local economy. Though I think the decrease was not as large as we might have imagined. And we'll talk to some of the reasons why later in this presentation. And for FY21 budget, there was a projection of about 3.5% increase from FY20 to FY21. And we don't have a full year's worth of FY21 data yet. But we're very curious to have that data commenced so that we can present the new and improved latest figures for you all going forward. 
SPEAKER_01:  We'll jump now into these comparisons across different geographic areas. So in this chart, we're looking at, you know, Long Beach compared to Los Angeles County, the general Southern California area and also the state of California overall. And so you can see that, you know, here on the chart that Long Beach has historically underperformed when you compare it to LA County, Southern California and the state of California, which we see here, there've been a few dips and I think it's safe to say that again, some of the dips from 4Q19, but especially 1Q2020 to about 3Q2020, were in large part due to the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on our local economy. One thing that you will see here in this chart is that over the last three quarters, so the third quarter of 2020, the fourth quarter of 2020 and the first quarter of 2021, we see that the per capita sales tax, that's been generated here in the city of Long Beach has stabilized for the most part. In some of the other areas that we're looking at here, there was an increase and then, currently on a decline. So it's interesting, they added it to see there and of course there's still some work to do to better understand, you know, the reasons behind some of the stabilizations in Long Beach compared to some of the other geographic areas that we're looking at here in this chart. 
SPEAKER_01:  So now we'll look at some cities that were recommended in an unincorporated area of LA County that was recommended by HDL companies, our sales tax provider that we contract with. So you can see that that Long Beach has historically performed stronger than Oakland and unincorporated LA County and Long Beach is a thick green line here on this chart. Long Beach continues to underperform compared to Sacramento. It looks like we have underperformed at least going back to the first quarter of 2018, a per the chart. And as I mentioned in the last slide as well, you do see that Long Beach has again over the last three quarters stabilized in terms of a per capita sales tax revenue that's generated. But that in these other cities you've seen kind of moderate increases from about three Q, a third quarter of 2020 to fourth quarter of 2020. But they're all currently declining. And we can see that sales Sacramento is declining at a faster rate than some of the other areas that are listed here in the city or on this chart. 
SPEAKER_01:  So what we have here, and on this chart, is the per capita sales tax surplus and gap comparison. This is what we've referred to in the past as a sales tax leakage report. So the chart looks at per capita sales tax generated across retail categories, a variety of retail categories. Here, I know it can be a little hard to see on the screen, but hopefully it's okay to see it with the presentation in front of you. And a retail surplus suggests that the community's capturing its local market for the category of goods, plus attracting additional shoppers from outside of the city of Long Beach. So there's the general kind of a net gain, and we're capturing our local share plus sum. A retail gap suggests that residents may have a greater demand for certain products in a specific category than is being satisfied by local businesses here in the city of Long Beach. And the information is provided really as a starting point in identifying some new opportunities based on, really only on Long Beach's population here that we're seeing. So there might be opportunities to possibly capture some sales tax revenue in some of the other retail categories or retail categories are listed here that are currently in a gap, where we're not capturing our fair share or local market share of the sales tax revenue. It over the years, really, as we deliver these presentations, for the most part, most of our retail categories that we've had a gap in as opposed to a surplus in. And currently, Long Beach has a surplus in casual dining, grocery stores, convenient stores, and liquor stores, and also fast casual restaurants. These have been some of the same categories that we've seen a surplus in the past. And we have the largest gaps in lumber and building materials, discount department stores, and electronics, and appliance stores. And the data is from the first quarter of 2021 going back for three other quarters. So it's about April 2020 to March 2021. Is what we're looking at here today. And the next step for us really is to look at the comparison of the first quarter of 2021 data going back a few quarters, to the first quarter of 2020 data going back a few quarters to see what the comparisons look like so that we can see the changes in the different retail categories and whether it's been a surplus or a gap. 
SPEAKER_01:  So this next slide here, we aggregate some of the retail categories. We had a longer list in the last chart. And we can see that there's only been an increase in a few industry groups. So the state and county pools, which we're going to dig into more a little later in this presentation, and then food and drugs. And I think it's slide possibly 15 or 17 in your presentation. We also have some, the major industry groups listed by some of the smaller retail categories, so that you can see, you know, the types of businesses that are included in the different industry groups. But just just an example, in food and drugs, we have food stores that are non-grushory. We also have grocery stores. We have convenience and liquor stores. We also have a cannabis related sales tax revenue as well.

We have seen decreases, pretty substantial decreases in restaurants and hotels, 31% decrease in this case, which speaks to the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on our local hospitality industry. Have seen a substantial decrease in fuel and service stations. So I imagine while we still need to dig into the details, I imagine that people weren't driving as much and working from home had an impact on that revenue that was generated, and then there was an 8% decrease on business and industry, which there's a lot of retail categories that are listed under that category of there. 
SPEAKER_01:  So let's dig in a little more into the pretty, pretty big increase in the state and county pools. So that is the share of tax revenue, that the per-radity share of tax revenue that the city gets from the state, tax revenue collected from the state and tax revenue collected from the county of Los Angeles. And I just wanna remind the council members that the financial management department they could provide and complete FY 20 year end budget report that spoke to some of the increases. And they spoke about the implementation of AB 147, which is the Marketplace Facilitators Act, and also the boost in online sales that resulted in, you know, due to the pandemic and people being hesitant to shop in person, and then of course the impacts of local state health orders on business operations. So AB 147 again is the Marketplace Facilitators Act. This required out-of-state retailers that meet specific requirements to collect and remit California's sales, use and transactions tax. While it was effective April 1st, 2019, Marketplace Facilitators that will define shortly were not required to begin reporting until October 1st, 2019. And basically as of October 2019, they were required to collect and remit taxes for out-of-state sellers who contract with them, directly or indirectly to facilitate sales. 
SPEAKER_01:  So a marketplace facilitator is a business that provides any of the following services. So payment processing, fulfillment, or storage services. List of products or sell, set prices, they take orders, or they provide customer service, or assist with returns or exchanges. 
SPEAKER_01:  So what you see now on the screen here, and some information that we got from HDL, again, the firm that we contract with to get all of the sales tax information, also some insights that we get from them as well. And they estimate that across the state of California, over 26 billion in taxable sales has been reported through new AB 147 accounts, and that it generated about $1.9 billion in state-wide sales and use tax revenue. And that again, you know, the COVID-19 pandemic, and the restrictions they had on business operations, did also boost online sales of remote sellers, and these marketplace facilitators that we keep talking about. And some examples of marketplace facilitators, or AB 147 tax payers include Amazon,

21-0663.summary: Recommendation to conduct, receive and file a Study Session,and receive input from Economic Development & Finance CommitteeMembers and members of the public for the implementation of aracially equitable economic recovery strategy to help Long Beachbusinesses and workers quickly and effectively recover from theeconomic hardship caused by COVID-19 as approved by the CityCouncil on March 16, 2021. John Keisler, Director of Economic Development, spoke; and provided aPowerPoint presentation.Chair Mungo spoke.Vice Chair Richardson spoke.Chair Mungo spoke.A motion was made by Vice Chair Richardson, seconded by Chair Mungo, to approve recommendation.  The motion carried by the following vote:Yes: 3 - Mungo, Richardson and Allen4.

21-0664.summary: Recommendation to conduct, receive and file a Study Session andreceive input from Economic Development & Finance CommitteeMembers and members of the public regarding the development ofthe Blueprint 2.0, the proposed 10-year plan to create equitable economic opportunities for workers, investors, and entrepreneursin the City of Long Beach through the year 2030.This Agenda item was laid over by consensus to the next Economic Development and Finance Committee meeting.5.
